G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 2.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 223, § 2, as the Defendant operates and owns property within the Commonwealth of Massachusetts.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 1.proposition: Venue is proper in this Court pursuant to G.L. c. 223, § 1, as the Plaintiff resides at the Property in Lynn, Massachusetts, where the events giving rise to this Complaint occurred.

G.L. c. 148, \u00a7 26E.proposition: Pursuant to G.L. c. 148, § 26E, and Massachusetts fire safety regulations, Defendant was required to provide functioning smoke detectors in common hallways of multi-family residential buildings.

*St. Germaine v. Pendergast*, 411 Mass..proposition: Defendant’s failure to comply with mandatory fire safety standards constitutes negligence per se under Massachusetts law. See, e.g., *St. Germaine v. Pendergast*, 411 Mass. 615 (1992).
*St. Germaine v. Pendergast*, 411 Mass..support_reasoning: The opinion expressly rejects negligence per se based on regulatory violations. The court states that violations of statutes or regulations do not constitute negligence per se under Massachusetts law but are only some evidence of negligence, and applies that rule to the safety-related building code and regulations at issue. It does not carve out any exception for mandatory fire or other safety standards, so citing this case for the proposition that failure to comply with mandatory fire safety standards is negligence per se misstates its holding.
*St. Germaine v. Pendergast*, 411 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “We do not construe a safety statute to establish a new civil cause of action without express terms or clear legislative intent to that effect… Nor do violations of a statute or regulations constitute negligence per se; they are only some evidence of negligence. See MacDonald v. Ortho Pharmaceutical Corp., 394 Mass. 131, 139-140 (1985); LaClair v. Silberline Mfg. Co., 379 Mass. 21, 28 (1979); Perry v. Medeiros, supra at 841.”

*Pridgen v. Boston Housing Authority*, 3.raw_text: *Pridgen v. Boston Housing Authority*, 364 Mass. 696 (1974) (landlords have a duty of reasonable care to maintain safe premises for tenants);
*Pridgen v. Boston Housing Authority*, 3.proposition: *Pridgen v. Boston Housing Authority*, 364 Mass. 696 (1974) (landlords have a duty of reasonable care to maintain safe premises for tenants);
*Pridgen v. Boston Housing Authority*, 3.support_reasoning: The court explicitly holds that a landowner/occupier (here, the Boston Housing Authority as landlord) owes a “common duty of reasonable care” to persons on the premises, and extends that duty to a trespassing child who became helplessly trapped in the landlord’s elevator shaft. The case discusses and adopts a general duty of reasonable care owed by owners/occupiers to persons on the premises and applies it to the landlord-tenant public housing context, thus supporting the proposition that landlords must exercise reasonable care to maintain safe premises for tenants (and, here, even for a trespassing minor once trapped).
*Pridgen v. Boston Housing Authority*, 3.relevant_excerpt: “We hold that as to the latter trespasser the owner owes a duty to exercise reasonable care to prevent injury or further injury to him, including, if necessary, the duty to take reasonable affirmative action. … In the recent case of Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707 (1973), this court stated that ‘we … create a common duty of reasonable care which the [owner or] occupier owes to all lawful visitors’… We now hold that the same common duty of reasonable care is owed by an owner to a trespasser who has become helplessly trapped on the premises to the owner’s knowledge.”

*Young v. Garwacki*, 380 Mass. 162 (1980.raw_text: *Young v. Garwacki*, 380 Mass. 162 (1980) (failure to fulfill statutory safety requirements may constitute negligence);
*Young v. Garwacki*, 380 Mass. 162 (1980.proposition: *Young v. Garwacki*, 380 Mass. 162 (1980) (failure to fulfill statutory safety requirements may constitute negligence);
*Young v. Garwacki*, 380 Mass. 162 (1980.support_reasoning: The opinion does treat statutory safety requirements as relevant to negligence: the court relies on G.L. c. 186, §§ 19 and 15, which impose duties on landlords to correct unsafe conditions and bar exculpatory clauses, and it characterizes those statutes as consistent with imposing tort liability for negligent maintenance of premises, including demised premises. However, the core holding is broader—a general common-law duty of reasonable care by landlords to tenants’ guests—rather than a narrow rule that any statutory violation constitutes negligence. The case therefore supports the general idea that statutory safety obligations can ground negligence liability, but it does not squarely adopt a per se “statutory violation = negligence” rule.
*Young v. Garwacki*, 380 Mass. 162 (1980.relevant_excerpt: "Our statutes do not support limiting a landlord’s negligence liability to areas under his control. General Laws c. 186, § 19, requires most landlords to exercise reasonable care to correct an unsafe condition of which the tenant or a code enforcement agency has given him notice. If a landlord fails to correct the condition within a reasonable time, the tenant or any person rightfully on the premises has a tort action against the landlord for injuries sustained. General Laws c. 186, § 15, renders invalid any lease clause which has the effect of indemnifying the landlord or exculpating him from ‘any . . . negligence ... on or about the leased . . . premises.’"

*Lindberg v. Rankin*, 372 Mass. 475 (197.raw_text: *Lindberg v. Rankin*, 372 Mass. 475 (1977) (landlord's obligations to protect tenants against foreseeable risks);
*Lindberg v. Rankin*, 372 Mass. 475 (197.proposition: *Lindberg v. Rankin*, 372 Mass. 475 (1977) (landlord's obligations to protect tenants against foreseeable risks);
*Lindberg v. Rankin*, 372 Mass. 475 (197.support_reasoning: This opinion is a procedural decision about the non-appealability of interlocutory rulings (specifically an order overruling a demurrer) and the impropriety of piecemeal appeals. It does not involve landlords, tenants, premises liability, or any duty to protect against foreseeable risks. Accordingly, it does not support the proposition concerning a landlord’s obligations to protect tenants against foreseeable risks and appears to be a miscitation or mix-up with a different case of the same name.
*Lindberg v. Rankin*, 372 Mass. 475 (197.relevant_excerpt:
This is an action of contract by which the plaintiff seeks to recover a balance of $970 allegedly for dental services rendered by him to the defendant at various dates in 1972. The defendant demurred to the declaration... We conclude... that the appeal is not properly before us and that it should be dismissed without considering the sufficiency of the plaintiff’s declaration.

... [A] litigant is not entitled to piecemeal appellate review of unreported interlocutory orders or rulings of a trial judge... until the case is in all other respects ripe for final disposition in the trial court.

*Kingston v. Meadow Green-Wildcat Corp.*.raw_text: *Kingston v. Meadow Green-Wildcat Corp.*, 19 Mass. App. Ct. 630 (1985) (negligent maintenance of common areas creating liability for injuries);
*Kingston v. Meadow Green-Wildcat Corp.*.proposition: *Kingston v. Meadow Green-Wildcat Corp.*, 19 Mass. App. Ct. 630 (1985) (negligent maintenance of common areas creating liability for injuries);
*Kingston v. Meadow Green-Wildcat Corp.*.support_reasoning: The provided opinion text is a criminal case about promoting a lottery and focuses on expert gambling testimony, discovery issues, grand jury practice, and consciousness of guilt. It does not involve premises liability, negligent maintenance, common areas, or personal injuries. Accordingly, this opinion does not support the proposition about negligent maintenance of common areas creating liability for injuries; it appears to be a miscitation or the wrong case text for the stated proposition.
*Kingston v. Meadow Green-Wildcat Corp.*.relevant_excerpt: After a Superior Court jury trial, the defendant was convicted of setting up or promoting a lottery in violation of G. L. c. 271, § 7. On appeal, he alleges error in the admission of expert testimony, the denial of his motion to dismiss the indictment, and certain of the trial judge’s instructions. We affirm.

*Sheehan v. Weaver*, 467 Mass. 734 (2014.raw_text: *Sheehan v. Weaver*, 467 Mass. 734 (2014) (affirming landlord's duty of reasonable care);
*Sheehan v. Weaver*, 467 Mass. 734 (2014.proposition: *Sheehan v. Weaver*, 467 Mass. 734 (2014) (affirming landlord's duty of reasonable care);
*Sheehan v. Weaver*, 467 Mass. 734 (2014.support_reasoning: The opinion excerpt concerns statutory strict liability under G.L. c. 143, § 51 and the definition of “building,” not the common-law tort duty of landlords. While the court notes that the Weavers did not challenge the negligence verdict, it does not analyze or affirm any general principle about a landlord’s duty of reasonable care; that duty is simply assumed in the background. Thus the case, as presented here, does not serve as authority for the proposition that it affirms a landlord’s duty of reasonable care.
*Sheehan v. Weaver*, 467 Mass. 734 (2014.relevant_excerpt: “The Weavers do not challenge the verdict of negligence but argue that the judge erred in permitting Sheehan’s claim under § 51.… For the foregoing reasons, we now overrule the holding in McAllister and determine that, in accordance with the plain language of the statute, and considered in light of the prior legislation it replaced, § 51 applies to any violations of G. L. c. 143 and the State building code.”

G.L. c. 93A, \u00a7 2 (unfair or decepti.raw_text: G.L. c. 93A, § 2 (unfair or deceptive practices of landlords);
G.L. c. 93A, \u00a7 2 (unfair or decepti.proposition: G.L. c. 93A, § 2 (unfair or deceptive practices of landlords);
